awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Integrating phylogenetic, genetic, and functional approaches to dissect the role of toxin tolerance in shaping Drosophila biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Unusual adaptations to the environment have long fascinated scientists and the public. There has been much research to understand the evolution of morphological structures (e.g., shape, color, size). However, far less is known about the evolution of novel biochemical adaptations and the impact of these adaptations on the biodiversity of the organisms in which they appear. Of particular interest is how these traits arise if they are costly to the individuals who harbor them. This research investigates the evolution of biochemical adaptations and the genetic and ecological mechanisms that shape them. The research explores the tolerance of insects (fruit flies) to potent toxins in mushrooms that they consume. By investigating the mechanism of toxin tolerance and how this unique adaptation is maintained in this model system, the research will enhance the general understanding of how novel traits emerge and shape biodiversity. This project also includes activities designed to increase public scientific literacy and familiarity with biodiversity by training teachers and students, from middle school to the undergraduate level (particularly from underrepresented minorities), and generating photographic identification guides for insect species associated with mushrooms.

Flies from some groups of Drosophila feed on both toxic and non-toxic mushrooms, and can tolerate high doses of potent cyclopeptide mushroom toxins that are deadly to most other multi-cellular organisms. This research tests hypotheses that predict that: 1) tolerance to these toxic cyclopeptides evolved multiple times; 2) the genetic mechanism of tolerance is not the same in all species; and 3) trade-offs between the physiological costs of tolerance and the benefits of access to a low-competition resource maintain tolerance. The mechanisms of tolerance and their evolution within different fly species are being characterized using metabolomic and transcriptomic analyses that are analyzed in a phylogenetic framework. To assess the genetic basis of variation in toxin tolerance, the researchers are performing artificial selection experiments and genome sequencing. Finally, observational and competition experiments are being used to identify how selective pressures maintain toxin tolerance in natural populations. In sum, this research will provide an in-depth evolutionary, ecological, and physiological assessment of a costly and novel biochemical adaptation, and its impact on biodiversity.

por.por_cntn:
Many species of Drosophila flies are generalists on Basidiomycota mushrooms, and all of their life stages make use of these hosts. These flies are also among the only eukaryotes known to tolerate the cyclopeptide toxins (including the notorious α-amanitin) found in Amanita mushrooms despite these mushrooms comprising only a small portion of their potential diet. This project endeavored are to understand 1) the phylogenetic history, genetic mechanisms, and physiological and ecological function of the novel trait of mushroom toxin tolerance, and 2) the role of toxin tolerance in shaping the biodiversity of these mushroom-feeding insects. We find that cyclopeptide tolerance has evolved multiple times in Drosophila, that the genetic mechanism of tolerance is not the same in all species, and that the maintenance of tolerance is due to the trade-offs between the physiological costs of the toxin and the benefits of access to a low competition resource. We are studying eastern North American Drosophila species to understand how a novel, but costly trait can evolve, be maintained, and impact the biodiversity of the lineage in which it arises.
Some of the major outcomes of the research include: 

• A US patent for mushroom toxin extraction.

• We found that two transitions from mushroom-feeding to vegetative feeding likely occurred within the quinaria group. 

• D. tripunctata, a species that exhibits both mushroom and fruit feeding, identified significant genetic variation in toxin tolerance. Thus tolerance thus has the potential to respond to selection.

• Using RNAseq on two quinaria group species, we found that feeding on a diet results in changes in expression in over 100 transcripts in both species, but we found only one transcript that was upregulated in the presence of toxin in both species.

• We examined the impact of the natural toxin mixture on survival and fitness on both tolerant and susceptible species in the radiation. As expected, the “tolerant” species produced adults on all four diets. Somewhat surprisingly, we found that the susceptible species representing five species groups within the immigrans-tripunctata radiation, could all survive at a lower concentration of the natural toxin mixture. Thus, there appears to be a greater probability that toxin tolerance evolved multiple times and that a gradient of tolerance is present within the radiation. 

• We generated a phylogenomic dataset for species in the immigrans-tripunctata radiation, the resulting phylogeny recovered the monophyly of all species groups including the quinaria group. We used the resulting phylogeny to formulate a hypothesis of the evolution of toxin tolerance. Our results suggest that the trait evolved once and has been lost multiple times. 

• We significantly altered the microbiome of the larvae by including three broad-spectrum antibiotics in the diet and measured survival on diets with and without a-amanitin. We found no evidence of an effect of an alteration of the gut microbiome on tolerance across the five tolerant species. Our findings thus far provide support for our hypothesis that the gut microbiome does not contribute to toxin tolerance.

• Responding to noxious stimuli (such as parasitoids) is important for all species. We find that D. neotestacea (a toxin tolerant species) is hypersensitive to the parasitoids stimuli. While the two species from the quinaria group, D. guttifera (toxin tolerant) and D. deflecta (toxin susceptible), do not exhibiting any response to the stimuli. 

• Tolerance to highly toxic host compounds is typically associated with specialized feeding behavior. Surprisingly, all cyclopeptide tolerant species in the immigrans-tripunctata radiation are generalists on white fleshy mushrooms. Larvae do not show any preference between edible or toxic mushroom based media. The results of a competition assay showed that when a competitor’s eggs are present on the preferred substrate (edible mushroom media) female flies will lay more eggs on the toxic mushroom media.

• Given the levels of broad polyphagy in the mushroom-feeders, we wanted to assess whether these species could tolerate toxins other than cyclopeptides and whether tolerance was a complex genetic trait. We reared seven Drosophila species (five tolerant, one susceptible) on diets with and without each toxin. We found that all species (toxin tolerant and susceptible) survived on the diet containing isoxazoles. These results differed significantly from what the patterns observed on the diet containing orellanine toxins. For this toxin class, all species showed significantly decreased probability of survival. 

Overall, this project provided important insight into how novel and adaptive traits emerge within species radiations.  These insights will advance our understanding of how organisms, including humans may effectively cope with or even  exploit environmental toxins.
